title: Ticket #5268: Fix manual page for condor_transfer_data
description: Per htcondor-staff email with Todd Miller, and acknowledgement by Todd Tannenbaum
remarks:
2015-Sep-23 15:16:05 by tlmiller: 
I came across the section of the manual for "condor_transfer_data", and
believe it could use a bit of clarification, as I found myself very (SUPER)
confused.
See: http://research.cs.wisc.edu/htcondor/manual/current/condor_transfer_data.html 

Some example text, below, and my confusion:

*"condor_transfer_data* causes HTCondor to transfer spooled data. It is
meant to be used in conjunction with the *-spool* option of *condor_submit*,
as in

condor_submit -spool mysubmitfile

Submission of a job with the *-spool* option causes HTCondor to spool all
input files, the job event log, and any proxy across a connection to the
machine where the *condor_schedd* daemon is running. After spooling these
files, the machine from which the job is submitted may disconnect from the
network or modify its local copies of the spooled files."

For "causes HTCondor to transfer spooled data":
In which direction, from what machine to what machine, and under what other
conditions, is data transferred? What is the order of events? Is this at
the end of the job or when data is first transferred to the sandbox on the
execute node?
What does it mean to "spool" all input files. What happens to them and
where do they go if "spooled"? Should this section point to a better
explanation of "spool"? Why or in what instances would I want this?

In which cases (desired or undesired) would the submission machine
disconnect from the network or modify its local copies of the spooled
files? What's different if "-spool" isn't used? I think the use of  "may"
with "or" also adds ambiguity here. Is a disconnection something that is
more prone to happen (not of the user's desire) if spool is used  or is it
a disconnection easier to recover from when using spool? How do I know
if/when/why the machine would disconnect -OR- modify it's local copies of
the spooled files?

"When the job finishes, the job has JobStatus = 4, meaning that the job has
completed. The output of the job is spooled, and
*condor_transfer_data* retrieves
the output of the completed job."
So condor_transfer_data retrieves the data from the spool and then copies
it to the submission directory? If not to the submission directory, then to
where?

2015-Sep-23 15:17:00 by tlmiller: 
        I agree.  The man page could be a lot better -- I think it was
trying to compactly explain the intended usage scenario, but ended up being
less helpful than a simple link to a longer introduction.

> For "causes HTCondor to transfer spooled data": In which direction, from
> what machine to what machine, and under what other conditions, is data
> transferred?

        The first sentence should probably read something like
"condor_transfer_data transfers a spooled job's output to the current
directory."  Hopefully that makes it clear that the transfer happens
immediately (when you call condor_transfer_data).

> What is the order of events? Is this at the end of the job or when data is
> first transferred to the sandbox on the execute node?

        Likewise, I hope this question is answered by the reformulation
above.
> What does it mean to "spool" all input files. What happens to them and
> where do they go if "spooled"? Should this section point to a better
> explanation of "spool"? Why or in what instances would I want this?

        I agree that the man page should point to a longer introduction, and
tend to think that we should just omit the smaller inline explanation. My
longer attempt to actually answer your questions follows.  (It may save you
some time to note here that the '-remote' option to condor_submit is
equivalent to '-spool -name'.)

        Suppose that you're working on your laptop.  You've made some clever
change to your Matlab code, or maybe just come some interesting data from
some instrument you attached to the laptop.  Either way, uploading files to
the submit node is a pain (whether it's using scp or if you don't have
access to gluster from your laptop or whatever); or maybe you're just not
sure which files you changed, and don't want to spend the time to transfer
all of them.  Instead of transferring files and then submitting a job, you
can use 'condor_submit -spool -name submit-3.chtc.wisc.edu ...' (or
wherever) and Condor will transfer the job's input files from your laptop to
the submit node for you.

        Rather than picking some random part of your home directory to store
your job's files, Condor (the schedd) takes responsibility for managing them
and stores them its 'spool' directory.  Once condor_submit has finished
transferring the job's input files, the job proceeds as normal with its
directory in spool effectively being its submission directory.  At this
point, the job is entirely independent of your laptop -- whether you
disconnect it from the network (because you went home, because it's low on
battery), change the files that were part of the job, or whatever.

        At some point, you learn that the job has finished.  (Condor can
send you mail. ;))  When you do, you can run condor_transfer_data to get the
output sandbox.  (Since the job's spool directory is its submission
directory, the output goes there.)  In older version of Condor, running
condor_transfer_data before the job finished may not have worked, depending
on file permissions.

        You can also use -spool without -name, in case all you want the
ability to continue to change your files while the job is in queue, but I
think we generally don't like it when people do that (it uses a lot of disk
space and can be abused in the presence of quotas).

2015-Sep-23 15:17:40 by tlmiller:
Lauren also mentioned a mail from ToddT that she found considerably more illuminating than the manual, and much shorter than my own. :)

2015-Sep-23 16:30:08 by tlmiller:
Proposal, pending a better example to crib from. 

\Description
Use \Condor{transfer\_data} to fetch a job's output after submitting it
with the \Opt{-spool} or \Opt{-remote} options.  You may call
\Condor{transfer\_data} at any time, but if you call it before the job
attribute \Attr{JobStatus} equals 4 (completed), you may not get the
all of the job's output.  Data transfer begins immediately and will be
complete when \Condor{transfer\_data} returns (unless an error occurs).
After transfer, the location(s) of output on disk will be the same as
if the job had not been submitted with the \Opt{-spool} or \Opt{-remote}
options.

For more details on HTCondor file transfer, please consult [FIXME].

For more information about why you might choose to use the \Opt{-spool} or
\Opt{-remote} options, please consult [FIXME].
